Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from my younger sister lighting up the screen: “Come to the café with us tonight! It’s been ages.” I smiled, thinking about how much she valued these little get-togethers, how we’d promised to include each other more, to build the kind of respect that comes from simply showing up. But as I pulled up to the curb, two travelers flagged me down, their arms waving, suitcases piled at their feet. “Can you help us load these? We’ll split the fare,” one said, already opening the trunk. I hesitated, knowing that as a taxi driver, I was expected to be professional, to help with luggage, to make every customer feel welcome and cared for. My sister’s message buzzed again, a gentle reminder of my promise to her. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—my family expecting my presence, my job demanding my attention. My hands hovered over the steering wheel, heart thumping, torn between the pull of family and the call of duty.
